name: Amy Ousterhout
content: Amy Ousterhout Amy Ousterhout Assistant Professor Computer Science and Engineering UC San Diego Office: EBU3B 3130 aousterhout@ucsd.edu Google Scholar About I am an Assistant Professor in Computer Science and Engineering at the University of California, San Diego. My research interests are in operating systems and networks. Prior to UCSD, I was a postdoctoral researcher in the NetSys Lab at UC Berkeley, where I worked with Scott Shenker and Sylvia Ratnasamy. I received my Ph.D. in 2019 from MIT CSAIL, advised by Hari Balakrishnan and Adam Belay, and I received a B.S.E. in Computer Science from Princeton University. Research My current research projects focus on designing efficient and high-performance systems for datacenter applications. Support for microsecond-scale tasks: Efficient CPU scheduling (Shenango, Caladan, and Scheduling Policies) Memory management and zero-copy serialization (Cornflakes) Leveraging new hardware features (xUI, Aspen) Resource disaggregation: Efficient and flexible far memory (Fastswap, Eden) Students Ryan Kosta Liam Arzola Ani Canumalla Linsong Guo Teaching CSE 120 - Operating Systems Principles, Spring 2023, Spring 2025 CSE 190 - Data Center Systems, Winter 2025, Winter 2026 CSE 221 - Graduate Operating Systems, Winter 2024, Fall 2024, Fall 2025 CSE 291 - Operating Systems in Datacenters, Fall 2022, Fall 2023 Publications The Benefits and Limitations of User Interrupts for Preemptive Userspace Scheduling Linsong Guo, Danial Zuberi, Tal Garfinkel, Amy Ousterhout NSDI 2025 Eden: Developer-Friendly Application-Integrated Far Memory Anil Yelam, Stewart Grant, Saarth Deshpande, Nadav Amit, Radhika Niranjan Mysore, Amy Ousterhout, Marcos K.
